docs.lead_paragraph: Packages of some Mexican food products sold in border stores contain unhealthful levels of lead, according to a study by scientists in El Paso and in Juarez, Mexico. The study also found that some Mexican erasers popular with schoolchildren and several samples of glazed clay pottery advertised as lead-free contained high levels of the heavy metal.

headline.main: Lead in Mexican Products Raises Concern

docs.abstract: Scientists in El Paso and Juarez warns that packages of some Mexican food products sold in border stores contain unhealthful levels of lead and that some Mexican erasers popular with schoolchildren and several samples of glazed clay pottery advertised as lead-free contain high levels of lead (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Scientists may have found a biological reason to explain why two people who witness the same event will, years later, often have different memories of what happened. It seems that every time an old memory is pulled into consciousness, the brain takes it apart, updates it and then makes new proteins in the process of putting the memory back into long-term storage. The fact that new proteins are made means that the memory has been transformed permanently to reflect each person's life experiences -- not the memory itself.

headline.main: Brain-Updating Machinery May Explain False Memories

docs.abstract: Scientists discover a brain mechanism that may explain why two people who witness same event will, years later, often have different memories of what happened; finding suggests that it may become possible to erase traumatic memories; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Let a doctor of a certain age talk long enough and you're bound to hear the gloomy pronouncement that medicine just isn't as much fun as it used to be. People often make the understandable mistake of assuming that ''fun'' in this context is simply an irritating code word for the money, autonomy and adulation doctors enjoyed before the managed care era. After all, how could continuous immersion in the worry and suffering of others ever create actual, literal fun?

headline.main: Medical Fun Lost, Alas, In a Shuffle

docs.abstract: Abigail Zuger Essay says 'fun' element in a doctor's practice is vanishing in era of reduced budgets and managed care (M)

keywords.value: HEALTH MAINTENANCE ORGANIZATIONS AND MANAGED CARE

docs.lead_paragraph: Two distressing facts about the nation's youth bode ill for their future well-being: American children today are fatter than ever and less fit than they were in the 1960's, when John F. Kennedy established the President's Council on Physical Fitness. The fitness bug that bit many adults has not carried over to the younger generation. There are many reasons for this sad state of affairs. As school budgets tighten, physical education classes are often curtailed or abandoned. One in four children gets no physical education in school, and Illinois is the only state that requires daily phys-ed for all children, kindergarten through high school. In most school districts, the idea of a sound mind in a sound body has been abandoned, despite evidence that physically active children tend to do better in school.

headline.main: Fitness Gap Is America's Recipe for Fat Youth

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on distressing problems of poor physical fitness and obesity among many of America's youth (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: For many people, drinking that morning glass of grapefruit juice -- especially if it is one of the growing number of brands fortified with calcium -- is matter not just of taste but a part of a healthy regimen. But a new study warns that the juice can pose a danger when people drink it with a variety of prescription drugs, because it can alter their effect.

headline.main: A Healthy Regimen, With a Hazard

docs.lead_paragraph: The explosion of knowledge about what role genetics plays in disease has altered the way medical care is being provided at the most basic levels, and many health professionals may not be up to the task. Researchers from the Georgetown University Medical Center in Washington, writing in a recent issue of Genetics in Medicine, found that 70 percent of practitioners surveyed had discussed genetics with their clients. Yet fewer than 10 percent of those people surveyed -- including physical therapists, speech and hearing therapists and social workers -- were confident in their training in these issues.

headline.main: Genetics: Blind Spot in Medical Training

docs.abstract: Researchers find that many health professionals may not be up to task of using new knowledge of genetics in their treatment of patients (S)
docs.snippet: The explosion of knowledge about what role genetics plays in disease has altered the way medical care is being provided at the most basic levels, and many health professionals may not be up to the task.    Researchers from the Georgetown University...

docs.lead_paragraph: In the fall of 1977 the American Cancer Society organized the first national ''Great American Smokeout,'' urging smokers to quit for a day. Within five years, Jerry Falwell founded the Moral Majority and Jane Fonda sold millions of aerobics videos. Dr. Ruth Clifford Engs, a professor of applied health science at Indiana University in Bloomington sees a connection. In her new book ''Clean Living Movements: American Cycles of Health Reform'' (Praeger), Dr. Engs shows how Americans' fervor for self-improvement occurs in spurts. And interest in health and religion usually occurs at the same time. Her book traces the nation's obsessions with food, diet and religion and describes a country of extremists, who embrace preventive health and rigid moral codes one generation only to rail against them the next.

headline.main: Book Maps a Nation's Spurts of Clean Living

docs.abstract: Interview with Dr Ruth Clifford Engs, author of new book Clean Living Movements: American Cycles of Health Reform; book traces nation's obsessions with food, diet and religion and describes a country of extremists, who embrace preventive health and rigid moral codes one generation only to rail against them the next; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Some scuba divers are at ease under the water but mighty uncomfortable on the diving boat. For help, they turn to over-the-counter seasickness medicines. This could be dangerous, a study says. Researchers at the University of Pittsburgh say the drugs seem to affect some divers' mental functioning and judgment.

headline.main: Drug Warning for Seasick Scuba Divers

docs.abstract: Study finds that over-the-counter seasickness medicines may diminish a scuba diver's mental functioning and judgment (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: To John Sirmans, the CT scan that doctors showed him last December looked like a pair of socks full of golf balls. But the socks were his lungs, and the golf balls were tumors. The cancer that had started in his kidney was advancing, despite three months of an experimental treatment at the National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute. Doctors feared that Mr. Sirmans, 51, the father of one child in high school and two in college, would not survive much longer.
docs.abstract: New experimental treatment for advanced kidney cancer involves transplant of cancer-fighting cells from immune system of brother or sister; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Some authorities think one reason college students engage in so-called binge drinking is that they believe it is more widespread than it really is. And so to combat the problem, some college officials have tried what they call the ''social norm'' approach: education campaigns telling students that abusive drinking is less common than they may believe.
